These kinds of things happen all the time. Do you have love in your heart? Is it real love? The kind of love that makes you feel that intangible joy in the pit of your stomach like a bucket of acid and nerves running around making you hurt and happy all over and head over heels? I believe it's that sort of love that sounds nice to me. I'm telling you I have love. And in this big game that we play - life - it's not what you hope for. It's not what you deserve. It's what you take. But I'm sick. I'm sick here now. I should be getting along now. I'm sick and I'm in love. I seem to be the sort of person who confuses the two. But I don't care. Because I love you. I love you and I'm sick. If you want to love me back I'll be good to you, I'll be goddamn good for you. I won't be mad if you don't know who said what. I won't punish you if you get the answer wrong. I can teach, and I can tell you. I know you don't love me now. Do you know who I am? No one special. Just a spoke in the wheel. Who was it that said "A man of genius has seldom been ruined but by himself?" It was the lovely Samuel Johnson, who also spoke of a fellow who was not only dull, but was the cause of dullness in others. But Samuel Johnson has never been hit by lightening. It hurts. It doesn't happen to everyone. It's an electrical charge that finds its way across the universe and it lands in your body, and in your head. What does that mean, "A spoke in the wheel?" Things go 'round and 'round, don't they, though? They do, they do. But I'll make my dreams come true. I just don't know where to put things. I really do have love to give. I just don't know where to put it. Run away to the seashore. It doesn't matter anymore. Doesn't matter anymore. Words dry up and fly away with the passing of the days. Eventually you just let the stone fall. What most people don't see is just how hard it is to do the right thing. People think that if I make a judgment call, that's a judgement on them, but that's not what I do, and that's something that shouldn't be done. I have to take everything and play it as it lays. Sometimes people need a little help, sometimes people need to be forgiven, and sometimes they need to be punished. It's a very tricky thing on my part to make that call. If you can forgive someone, that's the tough part. What can we forgive? That's the tough part, the tough part of walking down the street. I just wanted to come here to say something, something important, something that you said. You said that we would say things and do things, and not lie, not keep things back - these sorts of things that tear people up. Well, I'm going to do that. I'm going to do what you said, and I can't let this go. I can't let you go. Now, you listen to me now. You're a good person. You're a good and beautiful person. And I won't let you walk out on me. And I won't let you to say those things, those things about how stupid you are, and this and that. I won't stand for that. You want to be with me, then you be with me. You see? Strange things happen all the time. And so it goes, and so it goes. This happens. This is something that happens. peace. Nodin

Earlier this week I was both intrigued and disappointed in an official public interview conducted by CBC's The National, the victim being the NDP leader Jack Layton. It was organized in the fashion that a few previously chosen audience members recited compelling questions that are currently on the majority of the nation's mind, while an unprepared New Democratic leader found himself muddled and non-committal. However, that is quite unfair in his defence; the pressure that must overshadow his every scrutinized and dissected thought and word process, not to mention the very syntax of the message, which is supposed to represent the very ethics and ideology of the Party itself must be excruciating, especially in front of such a criticizing audience. Yet, I still found myself unfulfilled and unsatisfied by his answers, as much of the audience and Peter Mansbridge himself seemed to concur. He easily and directly answered those addressed questions, though, which precisely coincided with those specific issues that his party has consistently reiterated and have methodically organized, such as removing the GST tax from the basic child necessities for low-income families, showing more support for equality initiatives and Aboriginal relations, and setting aside almost 5 billion dollars to fund international development assistance and Canadian environmental technologies to encourage a more Earth-friendly future over the next 4 years. There were many instances later, though, which included much unrelated discussion and repeated reiterations of the obvious points to his lecture, although did not give any clear indication of a definite explanation. He simply gave very general and ideal answers to seriously concerned citizens whose democratic right entails questioning the eligibility and standards that their possible future leader bases their actions on. There were more than a few times when Layton simply stated what they "would" do under certain circumstances or what they plan to do for the good of the nation and its citizens, but gave no clarity to the methods by which they would be able to perform some these actions, or where they would obtain the proper resources. These, I believe, are the real answers that we need to hear when deciding on and selecting our proper representative to the rest of the world. Intermission: The National is now planning on having a similar intimate interview with Liberal and Conservative leaders, Paul Martin and Stephen Harper, respectively. I really doubt that they will perform any more effectively than Layton because I seem to have become disheartened once again at the ability for the Party system to present itself in a commendable light based on its representatives. We as citizens cannot be so utterly ignorant and gullible as to swallow the force-fed and, most disappointedly, completely unrealistic solutions to such complex problems that do not require idealistic comforts as much as committed resolutions and action. Personally, I would much rather prefer to base my vote (which is this year, unfortunately, invalid) on the morals upheld by individuals, and support someone who upholds similar principles, and follows through with his or her promises with integrity and valour, instead of electing a party with a somewhat corresponding vision, yet I personally cannot control those officials elected into his or her party by the leader himself or herself. I'm also starting to come to the conclusion that perhaps youth apathy in terms of governmental participation is better for our country than youths actually voting based on completely arbitrary qualities, or simply choosing by total randomness. An example came to me a few days ago when my friend who recently turned 18 admitted that he is basing the entirety of his vote to which candidate has the best-sounding name. The regional representative for the NDP, titled with the unfortunate surname of "Bush," is off of his list, as well as the Liberal representative, also known as Mr. Priest (my friend is a devote Wiccan). I believe his vote has already been decided by the appealing name, "Dennis Kucinich." Rolls off the tongue, doesn't it? Verdict: peace. Nodin

It doesn't interest me what you do for a living. I want to know what you ache for, and if you dare to dream of meeting your heart's longing. It doesn't interest me how old you are. I want to know if you will risk looking like a fool for love, for your dreams, for the adventure of being alive. It doesn't interest me what planets are squaring your moon. I want to know if you have touched the centre of your own sorrow, if you have been opened by life's betrayals or have become shrivelled and closed from fear of further pain. I want to know if you can sit with pain, mine or your own, without moving to hide it or fade it or fix it. I want to know if you can be with joy, mine or your own, if you can dance with wildness and let the ecstasy fill you to the tips of your fingers and toes without cautioning us to be careful, to be realistic, to remember the limitations of being human. It doesn't interest me if the story you are telling me is true. I want to know if you can disappoint another to be true to yourself; if you can bear the accusation of betrayal and not betray your own soul; if you can be faithless and therefore trustworthy. I want to know if you can see beauty, even when it's not pretty, every day, and if you can source your own life from its presence. I want to know if you can live with failure, yours and mine, and still stand on the edge of the lake and shout to the silver of the moon, "Yes!" It doesn't interest me to know where you live or how much money you have. I want to know if you can get up, after the night of grief and despair, weary and bruised to the bone, and do what needs to be done to feed the children. It doesn't interest me to know who you know or how you came to be here. I want to know if you will stand in the centre of the fire with me and not shrink back. It doesn't interest me where or what or with whom you have studied. I want to know what sustains you, from the inside, when all else falls away. I want to know if you can be alone with yourself and if you truly like the company you keep in the empty moments. -- Oriah Mountain Dreamer We began the preliminary packing of our lives here at home. Everything is lingering in a hazy, painfully morbid veil with only convoluted explanations and dishonest comfort. What should I do, where should I go? Dare I make a difference? Keep your patience, because it's one of the many parts of you that make me whole. What would happen to that fragile, yet voraciously predominant piece held in the invisible safe behind the lock-and-key within your own soul? Fade into the background, behind streaming credits and grow increasingly fraudulent and tainted with time. That's the worst case, however, for that key has been rubbed dull, and the lock has rusted to capture that piece forever; it may fade, but it may never be exchanged. But there are other targets as well, although these are not always discussed publicly. Among the most important of these is public both the world at large, and the highest priority - that of their own public. This holds true especially in a democracy, when one is fighting a war of choice - as in invading another country - instead of fighting a war of national survival. In such wars, issues like human rights and civilian casualties loom larger. Since such casualties are inevitable, special pains must be taken to explain them away. But how to do so? In a word, spin. Such is the conclusion of a just-released monograph, "Disappearing the Dead: Iraq, Afghanistan and the Idea of a New Warfare" by Carl Conetta of the Cambridge, Massachusetts-based Project on Defense Alternatives (PDA). Of course, the idea of shaping public opinion is hardly new. For example, a 1975 study by the Congressional Research Service, a division of the Library of Congress, in analyzing possible United States takeovers of Persian Gulf oil fields, wrote: "The administration, Congress, or both - assisted by the mass media - could take steps to sway public opinion one way or another if they believed it advisable." But the PDA documents how the Bush administration has taken spin to a new level. It notes that increased international and domestic attention to the collateral effects of military operations has been a persistent concern of the US defense community since the Vietnam War. And thus has it taken significant steps to minimize that concern. The "US Defense Department, State Department and White House conducted large-scale perception management" or "strategic influence" campaigns in support of Operations Enduring Freedom and Iraqi Freedom, as well as in support of the broader "war on terrorism" according to the PDA study. One of the Iraqi war incidents analyzed by the PDA was two market bombings in Baghdad that together claimed more than 70 lives early in the war. US and British authorities quickly suggested that these might have been the result of Iraqi air defense missiles falling back to the ground. But this was an unlikely scenario, according to the PDA study, for two reasons: the relative numbers of suitable weapons used by the two sides in Baghdad, and the attack vectors and performance characteristics of these weapons. In regard to the first point, coalition air-to-surface weapons outnumbered Iraqi surface-to-air missiles by a ratio as large as six-to-one. Second, minor errors and inaccuracies - even standard ones - in the delivery of air-to-surface missiles could have produced the market attacks. The PDA study states: "Shooting downward into thickly populated areas is simply a very dangerous and demanding endeavor. By contrast, for an air defense system to have been at fault would have required a string of errors and failures - some catastrophic - in the employment, performance, and functioning of both the system and its failsafe mechanisms." Nevertheless, US and British officials kept making this claim even after a British reporter found and confirmed that debris from the second marketplace bombing came from a US HARM anti-radar missile. Of course, such implausible claims could not have flourished without a complicit partner, the The PDA study states: "Spin is a form of misdirection on emphasizing the minor aspects of an event or promoting a tendentious or idiosyncratic interpretation of it - one that favors one's own interest. However, for spin to work, there must be a media willing to 'take the pitch' (so to speak), rather than letting it fall flat. With regard to the marketplace bombings; the news media's willingness to adopt the uncertainty frame and give the coalition 'the benefit of the doubt' divided along predictable lines. While the marketplace bombings reverberated loudly in the Muslim and Arab worlds, the story has no 'legs' in the United States and only short ones in Britain." Another tactic used by the Pentagon was what the study calls "lawfare"; the of both public perceptions and international law that aims to create or reinforce the impression that one's opponent is violating either the letter or spirit of the law. The goal is to undermine international and domestic support for the opponent's actions or causes. A case in point was the US-British framing of the Baghdad "shock and awe" air campaign. At the same time that coalition forces were bombing the city, they also complained about the legality of Iraq's placement of air defense systems in and around residential and industrial areas of the city. In this "the coalition's case [regarding] air defense was overstated", according to the PDA study. "It implied strictures that would have precluded any adequate air defense of the city - an outcome not consonant with the intent of international law. In fact it is not uniformly illegal to operate in or near civilian areas if such operations are militarily necessary. For better or worse, international law gives wide berth to military necessity." Particularly questionable were coalition complaints about Iraq placing air defense systems within 300 feet of residences. In fact there is no international law or rule of warfare that prevents that. Reached by phone, the study author, Carl Conetta said "their rhetoric implies that unless you place your systems at a distance from a target we chose to hit, that won't hit anyone, it's illegal. It's a typically Orwellian approach." - Exerpt from David Isenberg's "A Lesson in 'Disappearing the Dead,'" from Global Policy Forum Nodin

It was the Elephant Man's face that constantly reflected in my head - the deceptive tracks he laid down for a simple laugh out of his enraptured audience. On first reaction, I thought him to be an uncaring creature of misery, rolling out of his cot morning after the next for the prospect of a few dollars' reward. His story reverberated throughout the day, but now only his face remains; his callus tale and its disgusting details became almost entirely lost on me, yet the plastic veil of the elephant's face constantly burned in my eyes and reenforced the story's purpose. It reminded me of the way I will always watch films muted, with only its pretty colours projected out from the translucent screen, bathing the walls of my room in vague shades of reds, yellows, but especially the dingy, dry shadows of grey and white. It gives me a sense of importance, understanding, yet without any definitive certainty as to the sequence of events. It forces me to observe and comprehend sense in my own terms, instead of what others guide me into. I find that it also gives the film itself an aura of cosmic secrecy which cannot be simply deciphered, but worn away by assumptions and creativity, even if by the credits, its characters and meaning become mere fragments of truth and actuality in my mind as compared to the director's intentions. Filling the mouths of the muted characters carries in me a sensation of admiration and respect for those involved in the film's process, for they always present themselves as masterpieces in the eye of my mind; they're concepts completely out of my grasp of perception. Although this method may transport me into such an alternate state of consciousness that my existence seems insignificant and naive as compared to the uncertainty and untold passion of the swimming world around me, I realise that once I hit that mute button once again, the flood of discontent, superficialness, predictability, and undefinedness should drown my soul; in other terms, I realize that I deceive my own senses. However, what this man, Elephant Man, had done was inexcusable, for he had nowhere near the same intended impact that my own deception affects me, that is to strengthen my senses and open my heart to the potential and beauty of the living. The story that he recited for the God-knows-how-many-th time in that seaside boardwalk, behind that haunting elephant mask, recounted the death of his family in a brutal house fire set by his pre-pubescent daughter who was threatened to give up her cherished pet dog for sanitary reasons, but instead lashed out in such violent anguish with a gasoline can and her inside their house. His tone continually slackened and grew raspy and distant as time progressed, and the small group listening empathetically to him. That is, until he began laughing and confessed that he made up his gruesome tale. They applauded and saluted him with coins and paper bills, but my attention was spurred away by distain and resentment from the feeling of my deepest sorrow being manipulated for pleasure and entertainment. That became just another fork in the path, I find here and now, and it became another step in the wrong direction as it always does. Lying, under these tables, surrounded by naked chair legs, motionless but not blind. I watched, lids half-closed, watched the feet dancing and swaying under the lights, in tune with the blaring noise, the crowded and perilous streets beyond, and the tipped bottles soaking alcohol into my long hair, fanned out across the floor like slender, groping fingers, but always watching. So I continued along those streets, not yet crowded and noisy however, opposite to the direction of the Elephant Man; I used everything in my power to become clear of his essence, or perhaps it was just to escape the bitter taste of discomfort left in the back of my throat. Away from the sea, clearing the acrid sting of the salty air, and replaced by the congested stench of the city sidewalks. I became unaffected, however, and my detective sense of beauty slowly regained itself, so I unslung my camera and began shooting everything that lurks beneath the surface of this city life. The day, drawing into the twilight of summer, dragging the heat away by its feet to leave the purple afterglow of coolness on the cement. Title-ing, as I made my way: Cinco De Mayo, Early Man, Virgin at the Window, Puppeteer, The Scarlet, Prisoners of Hope... Idly sauntering down the concrete path, taking no notice of the hustle-bustle of ordinary lives skimming the surface, the only place that these lives may exist, like ghosts, while I make a detour into these depths. Before my sense regained and I resurfaced, I had unconsciously found my destination to be on the stoop of Jakob's house. The months of finding my second home here at his apartment had engraved this trail to his door, so while my mind and eyes wandered, my feet had not, but only brought me back full-circle. I know now, lying here, and I even knew then, that the choice to take those few familiar steps to the main door, and only one more flight to his own, I would have to take a step back in time and relive those regrets, those tears, those uncomforts. My fate denied the idea of a hidden benefit to this plan, and only perceived the reasoning to be a lack of faith and courage to go forward on my part, and a sense of defeat to linger in the past. What compelled me to do it? Closure couldn't have been an option, nor the longing for amends and an urge to regain that intimate connection. It had been something deep within the pit of my heart that cried out for console, but not from him, and retribution. So I mounted those steps, and walked into the lobby and began on the rickety, lifeless stairs. I reflected on the once sweet perfume of our relationship, and recalled the ticket stubs that still lie in the bottom of a box underneath my bed, signifying one of our first nights of authentic bonding. They were from the almost-forgotten tickets of a boxing match we went to see in the basement of a local gym. It may not have been the archetypical first date in most relationships, but then again, seeing a film had been ruled out due to my unorthodox habit. These thoughts, however, melted into the stagnant decay of our last few weeks as lovers, for our actual selves were uncovered during that time, and we agreed that the sight of one another was too unsettling to live with. The consideration that he may be drunk, or perhaps busy with another as I reached him had crossed my mind for a fleeting moment, but was dashed away when his door came into sight within the long, untended hallway of the building. To my relief, he had not been drinking, and had been, in fact, alone as I entered his apartment, confessing that I had no clear idea as to the purpose of my presence after we greeted each other. I told him that he looked well. Quite well, actually. But before I could get any more out, he told me that he was late for an appointment and was just going to leave, and suggested that I should join him and catch up, in case I had no other plans...or ulterior motives. I accepted, and we were on our way to the bar two blocks down, known as Our Spot to carouse and socialize. We talked and debated of the past and future on our way, and I unfailingly and deliberately warmed to him; the cold sense of vengeance that had been planted like a spark into my head as I approached his door had been snuffed out in such a reassuring breeze as his. I forgot those nights of lying in bed, awake no matter how low my eyelids drooped to listen for the faint jingle of keys in the doorway; the pleadingly, unquenchable urge to call up Pat out of spite and for satisfaction had dissipated; the guilt and shame he inflicted upon me when he adopted the role as the persuasive control switch during those long days and longer nights were pushed aside. So I walked with him, through the doors of the bar, and joined a seat with him, soon accompanied with his, and some of my, old friends. He make me realize, no, re-realize why I had chosen him out of the millions of other men outside in the big black world of the cold night, because right then and there, he rekindled his ability to make me feel as though I was the only person on Earth accompanying him, and made that world seem much smaller and warmer than it actually was. We looked into each other, and all the rest faded with our senses. My breaking point, I found. So I ended here, and here is where I lay now, reflecting on all this, which led up to this point. Why I should be so absently led around by a collar in the hands of my emotions, powerless as to the direction of my journey, and opening my eyes just to witness the extent of my destruction and lack of control, only to be left to pick up the pieces that have fallen and clean up these messes I cannot be accounted for? The lights pulsing on the floor, the tabletops, everywhere but down here with me and the beer soaking my hair and clinging my clothes to my skin. He slipped away from me again, from my exposed heart and open arms, to leave me crumpled in the corner, away from the world and bent to my emotional breaking point. Do I find something satisfying in deceiving myself, or is it the thrill of the outcome that spurs me on to exist, only to find that it pushes me back down? Or have I even gotten up at all? His feet sway and step in beat with the noise along with the rest of the others surrounding him. Here, lying with my pale cheek on the colder floor, I realize that given all of these facts of deception, it becomes so difficult for me to relax at the thought of such an easy death, and find that I tend to forget that I can't get shot in the back if I don't run from it. peace. Boy, I've had quite a lot of mixed emotions these past few days. Friday was giddiness and contentment, yesterday was exhaustion, amazement, and purely pissed off, and today...well, I guess it's pretty much just aching. I've got a feeling this'll be a looong entry, so let's begin at the beginning, hmm? On Friday, the ONLY interesting day that week 'cuz I had done nothing the days before, I took a ride with my mom and dad to Kamloops (one of the biggest cities in BC) because my mom had to see the specialist there about her condition which no one here had any idea what it is. So the ride there was boring as always, however as soon as we got about 45 minutes outside of Kamloops, everything got really smoggy and the air was choking with soot and smoke, due to the horrendously gigantic forest fire happening outside of the city. It's such a horrible sight to see. Anyway, when we got there, we first went to the mall...I forget its name...but, yeah, we grabbed an Orange Julius, then dad and I went to the sports store to look for a new bike helmet for me cuz the one I'm using now is from grade 3, and isn't quite fitting so well anymore for some reason...:p So we looked around, but there was nothing there. I then checked out the Bootlegger to see if there were any of the shorts that I bought in Calgary were there, but there was nothing cuz their new shipment of men's clothing was to come in the next week or so. Dinger. But I did happen to find an excellent olive tee that looks really good on me. Anyway, I then went to Thrifty's while dad went to look for mom at the Hudson's Bay, potentially getting lost there. ^.^ I soon discovered while hunting around Thrifty's that I prefer their fashions much more than any other clothing store I've been to. Their clothes are so simple, yet so eye-catching and original, as well as quite inexpensive and full of good quality, compared to the logo-riddled and garish apparel other stores advertise. So I bought this pair of shorts that look good as well. I also wanted this other shirt that would look quite smashing, however dad told me that it was one already, and mom wanted to be at the doctor's at quarter past, so we really had to hurry, and there wasn't enough time. Dinger again. So we dropped her off at the doctor's, and while the doctor-person-guy did some painful tests on her (including electrodes and jolts of electricity...ouch), dad and I went to Sports Mart and got a shiny cool new helmet pour moi. It was pretty hard to find a normal looking one, though...practically every one I looked at looked as though they were designed for hardcore mountain-bikers who like to show off all their expensive, flashy equipment that they use maybe twice a year. Anyway, I found one that was remotely simple and normal, then we headed over to the Office Depot to pick out a new office chair for me, once again, because my old one is a GREAT hazard (four-arm base), uncomfortable (practically just two flat cushions stuck at a 90 degree angle), and just plain useless. So, yay! I'm finally up-to-date with the rest of the modern world!...seat-wise...Yes, I'm very proud of my new comfy chair...it's all pretty and can rock, and goes up and down, and it's grey, and its got armrests, and it spins, and it's cool. :D Oh, I just about forgot about Thursday at Laura's. Well, I'll get back to that later. Um, yeah, anywho, we then had some lunch at the Great Canadian Bagel, which was exceptionally yummy, then picked up mom, who said that the damn doctors STILL don't know what's wrong with her...they checked her out from head to toe, (spine, legs, nervous system, brain) and still can't find anything. Yay to modern medicinal science. So, we went home, and I assembled the chair which I am currently sitting in...ahhhh... RIGHT, so, yesterday was quite rewarding as well. Dad and I had planned to go hiking up Mt. Sir Donald that day, so we got up at 7 and got on the road east to Glacier National Park to the trail head. It was an exceptionally sunny and the weather was delightful the entire day. The trip up to the campsite is about 4 km from the trail head, but the trip there is very steep, rocky and definitely not for novices, even though we saw about 6 people making their way down so early. It took us surprisingly about one and a half hours to reach the end of the trail and the campsite, which really wasn't anything great, for all three of us had done it a year ago, but it was still very nice...the sun was shining, lots of blue sky, and the water was so crystal clear and refreshingly cool. However, this was not our final destination, even though that's really as far as the trail is supposed to go. We headed up this steep, high moraine (a narrow trail with steep sloping sides off of its edges) which we precariously made our way across and lead us to a scree slope and several slippery snow patches which we had to cross in order to lead us to the Holy Grail, a huge cirque, known as the Sir Donald col. When we finally got there, after 3 hours of rigorous hiking from the campsite, it was worth every minute. I don't think I can even explain its true beauty or extravagance here...let's just say that it was, and I would recommend it to anyone who would think of trying it. It was amazing of the full spectrum of sky and distance in all directions that could be viewed from way up there...Anyway, there were quite a few people there, unsurprisingly, who were planning on climbing to the very top of the mountain the next morning and had set up several tents there, so dad and I took a breather and enjoyed the view. I took a few pics, then we made our way down. Oi vey. That was definitely the worst part about the trip. On the way up, I had barely eaten anything, and I had started to get a headache, which, I suspected, was simply due to a low blood sugar level, which I would take care of at the col. However, even after eating a lunch full of sugars, it still persisted, however not as strong. We made our way down, and it was pretty tough going, and by the time we reached the first campsite at the beginning of the real trail, my thighs were aching, my feet were sore with blisters, my calves were screeching, my lungs were on fire, and my head was pounding. I seriously could not have been more uncomfortable at that moment, however, I suppose I was wrong. The rest of way down was the worst...full of rocks, outcrops, sunburns, stumbles, exhaustion, and so forth. This was literally my first hiking trip of the season since last year, and I was pretty unprepared for it...Oh well, I suppose it was worth it...Back home, I took a warm bath that seemed to help, later rested in my agony...:p Sure, I may be over-emphasizing it all, but I swear it was agonizing...I'm still sore all over my body.
